title: Maintainer Notes
code: # Add to .Renviron (NEVER commit this file) R2_ACCOUNT_ID="your_account_id" R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID="your_access_key_id" R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="your_secret_access_key"

title: Maintainer Notes
text: Settings > Secrets variables > Actions > Add: - R2_ACCOUNT_ID - R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID - R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY

title: Maintainer Notes
text: Cloudflare Dashboard > R2 > Manage R2 API Tokens Create new token (Object Read & Write, bucket: nascar-data) Update .Renviron GitHub Secrets Delete old token

title: Maintainer Notes
text: R2 single source truth. data bundled package.

title: Maintainer Notes
text: Runs every Monday 10:00 UTC (5:00 EST). Manual trigger: Actions tab > Weekly NASCAR Data Update > Run workflow. scraper.R downloads existing data R2 Scrapes new races DriverAverages.com Combines old + new uploads back R2 validate_data.R downloads R2 validates Commits .checksums.json main

title: Maintainer Notes
code: # Upload local rda files to R2 as parquet (one-time or recovery) Rscript inst/updates/upload_to_r2.R  # Dry run (no actual upload) Rscript inst/updates/upload_to_r2.R --dry-run

title: Maintainer Notes
code: # Requires R2 credentials in .Renviron + paws.storage, arrow, httr2 source("R/r2_upload.R") source("inst/updates/scraper.R") update_nascar_series("cup") update_nascar_series("nxs") update_nascar_series("truck")

title: Maintainer Notes
text: Bucket: nascar-data Region: WNAM Custom domain: nascar.kylegrealis.com Files: cup_series.parquet, nxs_series.parquet, truck_series.parquet

title: Maintainer Notes
text: new tracks added NASCAR schedule: 1. Update relevant inst/updates/*_track_info.rda file 2. Include: Track name (must match DriverAverages.com), Length, Surface

title: Maintainer Notes
text: dataset uses nxs_series identifier NASCAR’s second-tier series. “NXS” NASCAR’s sponsor-neutral abbreviation. series changed title sponsors four times (Busch, Nationwide, Xfinity, O’Reilly Auto Parts), stable abbreviation prevents codebase going stale sponsor change.

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: NASCAR one top-tier racing sports North America competes F1 IndyCar top viewership spot. Approximately 3.22 million people watch race given weekend throughout season. nascaR.data package result wanting share passion sport provide option typical go-packages learning new data visualization tools. nascaR.data packed full NASCAR results dating back first Daytona Beach race 1949! Use package discover race trends across NASCAR Cup Series, NXS (formerly Xfinity Series), Craftsman Truck Series. Answer questions like “driver best average finish short tracks?”, “team’s performance changed time?”, see manufacturer dominated series certain season. ’s , let’s strap race seats, fire engines, let’s take warm-laps.

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: nascaR.data provides access 3 datasets race--race results NASCAR series, plus 3 helper functions make exploring data easier. Let’s check gauges see ’s hood: package provides data three series via load_series(): - load_series("cup"): NASCAR Cup Series races 1949-present - load_series("nxs"): NASCAR NXS races 1982-present - load_series("truck"): NASCAR Truck Series races 1995-present dataset contains race results 21 columns including driver, team, manufacturer, finishing position, laps led, . Use ?load_series view complete list variable descriptions. package also provides helper functions built-fuzzy matching quickly analyze drivers, teams, manufacturers: * get_driver_info(), get_team_info(), get_manufacturer_info(): Get career statistics
code: library(nascaR.data)  # Load data from cloud storage cup_series <- load_series("cup")

what: Which drivers are in the Top 5 for wins in the NASCAR Cup Series?
title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: First, calculate total wins driver. , organize drivers descending order wins, subset keep Top 5 winningest drivers, feed data horizontal bar chart (tweaks applied enhance visual output).  Wow! doesn’t even look like close race. Richard Petty clearly leads field 200 wins. However, let’s take drive little deeper turn account number races driver competed . compare five drivers win percentage?  Accounting total races run, see different story emerge. David Pearson’s win percentage leads pack 18.3%, followed Richard Petty 16.9%. Imagine many wins Pearson accumulated competed many races King.
code: cup_series |>   group_by(Driver) |>   summarize(career_wins = sum(Win, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   arrange(desc(career_wins)) |>   slice_head(n = 5) |>   ggplot(aes(Driver, career_wins)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity") +   coord_flip() cup_series |>   group_by(Driver) |>   summarize(     career_wins = sum(Win, na.rm = TRUE),     total_races = n(),     win_pct = career_wins / total_races   ) |>   arrange(desc(career_wins)) |>   slice_head(n = 5) |>   ggplot(aes(Driver, win_pct)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity") +   coord_flip()

what: Modern driver performance: Analyzing race results
title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: Let’s shift gears look modern drivers stack . Win column datasets makes easy filter race victories analyze performance trends. Christopher Bell 13 Cup Series victories. Let’s compare performance across different track types see excels. Road courses show strong average finish, let’s visualize performance trends time see full picture.  trend shows consistent improvement, better average finishes recent seasons. Lower numbers better, reversed y-axis makes clearer.
code: # Get all wins for a specific driver bell_wins <- cup_series |>   filter(Driver == "Christopher Bell", Win == 1) |>   arrange(desc(Season))  # How many Cup Series wins? nrow(bell_wins) ## [1] 13 # Average finish by track surface cup_series |>   filter(Driver == "Christopher Bell", Season >= 2020) |>   group_by(Surface) |>   summarize(     races = n(),     avg_finish = round(mean(Finish, na.rm = TRUE), 1),     wins = sum(Win, na.rm = TRUE),     laps_led = sum(Led, na.rm = TRUE)   ) |>   arrange(avg_finish) ## # A tibble: 4 × 5 ##   Surface races avg_finish  wins laps_led ##   <chr>   <int>      <dbl> <dbl>    <int> ## 1 road       31       13.4     3      121 ## 2 dirt        3       14       1      100 ## 3 paved     181       14.8     9     2501 ## 4 NA          2       16       0        4 # Visualize season-by-season performance cup_series |>   filter(Driver == "Christopher Bell", Season >= 2020) |>   group_by(Season) |>   summarize(     avg_finish = mean(Finish, na.rm = TRUE),     wins = sum(Win, na.rm = TRUE)   ) |>   ggplot(aes(Season, avg_finish)) +   geom_line(color = "#fb9f00", linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(aes(size = wins), color = "#fb9f00") +   scale_y_reverse() +   theme_minimal() ## Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range ## (`geom_line()`). ## Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range ## (`geom_point()`).

what: Which manufacturer has the best performance by season?
title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: Let’s go behind pit wall see manufacturers Cup Series. ’ll look average finish position get comprehensive view performance.  Toyota Chevrolet trading competitive positions, showing strong performance recent years. Ford shown improvement since 2015, Dodge exited series 2012.
code: cup_series |>   filter(Season >= 2010) |>   group_by(Season, Make) |>   summarize(avg_finish = mean(Finish, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   ggplot(aes(Season, avg_finish, group = Make, color = Make)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   scale_y_reverse()

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: top teams compare driving different manufacturers? Let’s look Joe Gibbs Racing’s transition Chevrolet Toyota. Joe Gibbs Racing switched Toyota 2008, performance data tells story partnership’s success following years.
code: cup_series |>   filter(Team == "Joe Gibbs Racing", Season >= 2000) |>   group_by(Season, Make) |>   summarize(     races = n(),     wins = sum(Win, na.rm = TRUE),     avg_finish = round(mean(Finish, na.rm = TRUE), 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   select(Season, Make, races, wins, avg_finish) ## # A tibble: 27 × 5 ##    Season Make      races  wins avg_finish ##     <int> <chr>     <int> <dbl>      <dbl> ##  1   2000 Pontiac      68    10        9.9 ##  2   2001 Pontiac      72     5       13.3 ##  3   2002 Pontiac      72     4       16.2 ##  4   2003 Chevrolet    73     4       15.5 ##  5   2004 Chevrolet    77     2       15.1 ##  6   2005 Chevrolet   107     5       19.3 ##  7   2006 Chevrolet   108     7       17.1 ##  8   2007 Chevrolet   109     4       16.8 ##  9   2008 Toyota      109    10       14.5 ## 10   2009 Toyota      111     9       16.5 ## # ℹ 17 more rows

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: nascaR.data package includes helper functions make data exploration easier. functions handle fuzzy matching, don’t need type exact names.

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: get_driver_info() function provides three types output: * 'summary': Career totals series * 'season': Season--season breakdown * '': Complete race--race results
code: # Get comprehensive driver statistics (handles fuzzy matching) get_driver_info("bell", series = "cup", type = "summary") # Season-by-season performance get_driver_info("Christopher Bell", series = "cup", type = "season")

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: helper functions work teams manufacturers: functions make quick explore data without memorizing exact spellings worrying capitalization.
code: # Get team statistics (fuzzy matching built in) get_team_info("gibbs", series = "cup", type = "summary")  # Get manufacturer performance across all series get_manufacturer_info("Toyota", series = "all", type = "season")

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: Let’s use helper functions compare several drivers’ performance specific track. comparison shows different drivers perform track, accounting starting position, finishing position, laps led.
code: # Compare drivers at Martinsville (short track) drivers_to_compare <- c("Christopher Bell", "Kyle Larson", "William Byron")  martinsville_comparison <- cup_series |>   filter(     Driver %in% drivers_to_compare,     Track == "Martinsville Speedway",     Season >= 2020   ) |>   group_by(Driver) |>   summarize(     races = n(),     wins = sum(Win, na.rm = TRUE),     avg_finish = round(mean(Finish, na.rm = TRUE), 1),     avg_start = round(mean(Start, na.rm = TRUE), 1),     laps_led = sum(Led, na.rm = TRUE)   ) |>   arrange(avg_finish)  martinsville_comparison ## # A tibble: 3 × 6 ##   Driver           races  wins avg_finish avg_start laps_led ##   <chr>            <int> <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>    <int> ## 1 Kyle Larson         10     1        6.2       7        332 ## 2 William Byron       12     3       10.5      10.7      664 ## 3 Christopher Bell    12     1       14.8      15.2      184

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: vignette gives foundation exploring NASCAR data nascaR.data package. Use load_series() access comprehensive race results three series, get_*_info() helper functions make data exploration straightforward built-fuzzy matching. ’s plenty opportunity analyze data: - Compare performance different track types (oval, road course, superspeedway) - Analyze rule changes affected competition - Track evolution manufacturer dominance decades - Examine relationship qualifying position race results - Study teams perform different drivers data updated regularly throughout season, ’ll always access latest race results. Whether ’re creating visualizations, building models, just exploring NASCAR history, package covered.

title: A Race Winning Strategy
text: nascaR.data built R version 4.5.2 tidyverse (2.0.0) ggtext (0.1.2) packages used preprocess summarize data.

title: Upgrading to v3
text: changed: cup_series, xfinity_series, truck_series datasets longer bundled package. data now served Cloudflare R2. (v2.x): (v3.0.0): : Bundling large datasets package made installation slow increased package size. Serving data R2 local caching provides faster updates smaller package downloads.
code: data("cup_series") data("xfinity_series") data("truck_series") cup <- load_series("cup") nxs <- load_series("nxs") truck <- load_series("truck")

title: Upgrading to v3
text: changed: second-tier series identifier changed "xfinity" "nxs". (v2.x): (v3.0.0): : second-tier NASCAR series changed title sponsors four times: Busch (1984-2007), Nationwide (2008-2014), Xfinity (2015-2025), O’Reilly Auto Parts (2026-present). “NXS” NASCAR’s sponsor-neutral abbreviation series, never go stale future sponsor changes. Note: Series column returned data now shows "NXS" instead "Xfinity". Update code filters Series == "Xfinity".
code: xfinity <- load_series("xfinity") get_driver_info("bell", series = "xfinity") nxs <- load_series("nxs") get_driver_info("bell", series = "nxs")

title: Upgrading to v3
text: changed: arrow package moved Suggests Imports. now required dependency. : data stored Parquet files R2. arrow package required read data efficiently. Action required: None. arrow package installed automatically install nascaR.data v3.0.0.

title: Upgrading to v3
text: works: First call session: Downloads data R2 caches memory Subsequent calls session: Instant retrieval memory cache New R session: Downloads fresh data R2 automatically new R session fetches latest data, always --date race results without manual intervention. Managing cache:
code: # Force fresh download within a session cup <- load_series("cup", refresh = TRUE)  # Reset the in-memory cache clear_cache()

title: Upgrading to v3
text: changed: find_driver(), find_team(), find_manufacturer() removed. (v2.x): (v3.0.0): : get_*_info() functions already include fuzzy matching return actual data. find_*() functions redundant.
code: find_driver("bell") get_driver_info("Christopher Bell") # Just use get_*_info() directly get_driver_info("bell")

title: Upgrading to v3
text: underlying race data unchanged. delivery mechanism series identifier updated. historical results remain available: Cup Series: 1949-present NXS: 1982-present Truck Series: 1995-present

code: @Manual{,   title = {nascaR.data: NASCAR Race Data},   author = {Kyle Grealis},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 3.0.0},   url = {https://www.kylegrealis.com/nascaR.data/}, }

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: nascaR.data provides historical race results NASCAR’s top three series: Cup (1949-present), NXS (1982-present), Trucks (1995-present). Explore driver, team, manufacturer performance race--race, season, career format. data expertly curated scraped permission DriverAverages.com. Note v3.0.0: second-tier series identifier changed "xfinity" "nxs". See vignette("migrating--nxs") details.

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: Install CRAN: install development version GitHub: Note: package requires arrow package reading parquet data cloud storage. installed automatically.
code: install.packages("nascaR.data") remotes::install_github("kyleGrealis/nascaR.data")

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: data served cloud storage. Use load_series() access race results: Data cached memory current R session. new session downloads fresh data automatically. Use refresh = TRUE force re-download within session. Data updated automatically every Monday racing season (February November).
code: library(nascaR.data)  cup <- load_series("cup") nxs <- load_series("nxs") truck <- load_series("truck")

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: NASCAR one top-tier racing sports North America competes Formula-1 IndyCar top viewership spot. Approximately 3.22 million people watch race given weekend throughout season. nascaR.data package result wanting share passion sport provide option typical go-packages learning new data cleaning & visualization tools.

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: Three series available via load_series(): load_series("cup"): NASCAR Cup Series race results (1949-present) load_series("nxs"): NASCAR NXS (second-tier) race results (1982-present) load_series("truck"): NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series results (1995-present) dataset contains detailed race information including: Race details (Season, Race number, Track, Name) Results (Finish position, Start position) Performance metrics (Laps completed, Laps led, Points earned) Driver team information Data sourced permission DriverAverages.com automatically updated every Monday 5AM EST racing season (February November).

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: Load package:
code: library(nascaR.data)

title: NASCAR Race Data
text: Use suite get_*_info() functions examine specific performance results race--race, season, career level. search race team manufacturer:
code: # Career results across all series get_driver_info("Christopher Bell") Driver: Christopher Bell # A tibble: 3 × 8   Series Seasons `Career Races`  Wins `Best Finish` `Avg Finish` `Laps Raced` `Laps Led`   <chr>    <int>          <int> <dbl>         <int>        <dbl>        <int>      <int> 1 Cup          6            216    13             1         14.5        54607       2717 2 NXS          7             81    19             1         10.3        13092       3272 3 Truck        7             58     7             1          8.4         8213       1246 # Season results across all series get_driver_info("Christopher Bell", type = "season") Driver: Christopher Bell # A tibble: 20 × 8    Series Season Races  Wins `Best Finish` `Avg Finish` `Laps Raced` `Laps Led`    <chr>   <int> <int> <dbl>         <int>        <dbl>        <int>      <int>  1 Cup      2020    36     0             3         20.2         9428         18  2 Cup      2021    36     1             1         15.8         8911        100  3 Cup      2022    36     3             1         13.8         8816        573  4 Cup      2023    36     2             1         12.9         8868        599  5 Cup      2024    35     3             1         12.8         9298       1145  6 Cup      2025    35     4             1         11.2         9286        282  7 NXS      2017     8     1             1         11.5         1423        156  8 NXS      2018    32     7             1         11.1         5112        759  9 NXS      2019    31     8             1          9.1         5574       2005 10 NXS      2021     2     1             1          3.5          300        174 11 NXS      2022     1     0             7          7            147          0 12 NXS      2024     2     2             1          1            353        151 13 NXS      2025     2     0            25         32            183         27 14 Truck    2015     7     1             1         11.9         1018        111 15 Truck    2016    23     1             1          9.5         3237        197 16 Truck    2017    23     5             1          5.7         3247        875 17 Truck    2018     1     0            28         28            184         31 18 Truck    2023     2     0             4         10            312          0 19 Truck    2024     1     0             5          5            134          2 20 Truck    2025     1     0             4          4             81         30 get_team_info("Joe Gibbs Racing") get_manufacturer_info("Toyota")

title: Clear Cached NASCAR Data — clear_cache
text: Clears -memory cache next call load_series() re-download cloud storage. Also removes leftover disk cache previous package versions.

title: Clear Cached NASCAR Data — clear_cache
code: clear_cache()

title: Clear Cached NASCAR Data — clear_cache
text: Invisibly returns NULL.

title: Clear Cached NASCAR Data — clear_cache
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Clear in-memory cache clear_cache()  # Next call downloads fresh data cup <- load_series("cup") } # }

what: Get Driver Info with Smart Matching — get_driver_info
title: Get Driver Info with Smart Matching — get_driver_info
text: Search driver name return career statistics. Supports partial names, typos, case-insensitive input via built-fuzzy matching engine.

title: Get Driver Info with Smart Matching — get_driver_info
code: get_driver_info(driver, series = "all", type = "summary", interactive = TRUE)

title: Get Driver Info with Smart Matching — get_driver_info
text: driver Character string driver name search . Supports partial names common misspellings (e.g., "earnhart" finds Earnhardt). series Character string ("cup", "nxs", "truck", "") pre-loaded data frame. Default "". type Character string specifying return format: "summary" Career totals grouped series (Seasons, Career Races, Wins, Best Finish, Avg Finish, Laps Raced, Laps Led). "season" Season--season breakdown (Races, Wins, Best Finish, Avg Finish, Laps Raced, Laps Led). "" Complete race--race results. interactive Logical. TRUE (default) R session interactive, prompts user select multiple matches. FALSE, silently uses first match.

title: Get Driver Info with Smart Matching — get_driver_info
text: tibble driver statistics (format depends type), invisible(NULL) match found.

title: Get Driver Info with Smart Matching — get_driver_info
code: # \donttest{ # Career summary across all series get_driver_info("Christopher Bell") #> Driver: Christopher Bell #> # A tibble: 3 × 8 #>   Series Seasons `Career Races`  Wins `Best Finish` `Avg Finish` `Laps Raced` #>   <chr>    <int>          <int> <dbl>         <int>        <dbl>        <int> #> 1 Cup          7            217    13             1         14.6        54798 #> 2 NXS          7             81    19             1         10.3        13092 #> 3 Truck        7             58     7             1          8.4         8213 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: `Laps Led` <int>  # Season-by-season Cup data get_driver_info(   "Christopher Bell",   series = "cup",   type = "season" ) #> Driver: Christopher Bell #> # A tibble: 7 × 8 #>   Series Season Races  Wins `Best Finish` `Avg Finish` `Laps Raced` `Laps Led` #>   <chr>   <int> <int> <dbl>         <int>        <dbl>        <int>      <int> #> 1 Cup      2020    36     0             3         20.2         9428         18 #> 2 Cup      2021    36     1             1         15.8         8911        100 #> 3 Cup      2022    36     3             1         13.8         8816        573 #> 4 Cup      2023    36     2             1         12.9         8868        599 #> 5 Cup      2024    35     3             1         12.8         9298       1145 #> 6 Cup      2025    35     4             1         11.2         9286        282 #> 7 Cup      2026     1     0            35         35            191          9 # }

Default "". type Character string specifying return format: "summary" Career totals grouped series (Seasons, Races, Wins, Best Finish, Avg Finish, Laps Raced, Laps Led). "season" Season--season breakdown (Races, Wins, Best Finish, Avg Finish, Laps Raced, Laps Led). "" Complete race--race results. interactive Logical. TRUE (default) R session interactive, prompts user select multiple matches. FALSE, silently uses first match.

Supports partial names common misspellings (e.g., "gibbs" finds Joe Gibbs Racing). series Character string ("cup", "nxs", "truck", "") pre-loaded data frame. Default "". type Character string specifying return format: "summary" Career totals grouped series (Seasons, Career Races, # Drivers, Wins, Best Finish, Avg Finish, Laps Raced, Laps Led). "season" Season--season breakdown (Races, # Drivers, Wins, Best Finish, Avg Finish, Laps Raced, Laps Led). "" Complete race--race results. interactive Logical. TRUE (default) R session interactive, prompts user select multiple matches. FALSE, silently uses first match.

title: Get Team Info with Smart Matching — get_team_info
text: tibble team statistics (format depends type), invisible(NULL) match found.

title: Get Team Info with Smart Matching — get_team_info
code: # \donttest{ # Career summary across all series get_team_info("Joe Gibbs Racing") #> Team: Joe Gibbs Racing #> # A tibble: 3 × 9 #>   Series Seasons `Career Races` `# of Drivers`  Wins `Best Finish` `Avg Finish` #>   <chr>    <int>          <int>          <int> <dbl>         <int>        <dbl> #> 1 Cup         35           3319             29   227             1         14.5 #> 2 NXS         30           2344             79   221             1         12.9 #> 3 Truck        4             66              3     0             2         16.5 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: `Laps Raced` <int>, `Laps Led` <int>  # Season-by-season Cup data get_team_info(   "Joe Gibbs Racing",   series = "cup",   type = "season" ) #> Team: Joe Gibbs Racing #> # A tibble: 35 × 9 #>    Series Season Races `# of Drivers`  Wins `Best Finish` `Avg Finish` #>    <chr>   <int> <int>          <int> <dbl>         <int>        <dbl> #>  1 Cup      1992    28              1     0             2         17.8 #>  2 Cup      1993    29              1     1             1         12.4 #>  3 Cup      1994    28              1     1             1         18.7 #>  4 Cup      1995    28              1     3             1         16.3 #>  5 Cup      1996    27              1     1             1         17.4 #>  6 Cup      1997    31              1     1             1         13.7 #>  7 Cup      1998    32              1     2             1         14.2 #>  8 Cup      1999    34              2     8             1          9.6 #>  9 Cup      2000    34              2    10             1          9.9 #> 10 Cup      2001    36              2     5             1         13.3 #> # ℹ 25 more rows #> # ℹ 2 more variables: `Laps Raced` <int>, `Laps Led` <int> # }

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
text: Downloads NASCAR series data Cloudflare R2 parquet file. Data cached memory current R session repeated calls instant. new R session downloads fresh data, ensuring always latest results.

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
code: load_series(series = c("cup", "nxs", "truck"), refresh = FALSE)

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
text: series Character. series load. One "cup", "nxs", "truck". refresh Logical. TRUE, bypass -memory cache re-download cloud storage. Default FALSE.

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
text: data frame 21 columns race results: Season, Race, Track, Name, Length, Surface, Finish, Start, Car, Driver, Team, Make, Pts, Laps, Led, Status, S1, S2, S3, Rating, Win.

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
text: NASCAR's NXS uses sponsor-neutral identifier "nxs" rather sponsor name. series sponsored Busch (1984-2007), Nationwide (2008-2014), Xfinity (2015-2025), O'Reilly Auto Parts (2026-present). Using "nxs" keeps identifier stable across sponsor changes.

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
text: Data cached memory current R session. Repeated calls return instantly without re-downloading. Starting new R session always fetches latest data R2. Use refresh = TRUE force re-download within session, clear_cache() reset -memory cache.

title: Load NASCAR Series Data — load_series
code: # \donttest{ # Load Cup Series data (downloads on first call, cached after) cup <- load_series("cup")  # Load NXS data nxs <- load_series("nxs")  # Load Truck Series data truck <- load_series("truck")  # Force re-download from cloud storage cup <- load_series("cup", refresh = TRUE) # }

title: NASCAR Series Data — series_data
text: Historical race results NASCAR's three major national series, sourced permission DriverAverages.com. Data hosted Cloudflare R2 accessed via load_series().

title: NASCAR Series Data — series_data
text: NASCAR Cup Series sport's premier division. Originally called Strictly Stock Series inaugural 1949 season, known several names tied title sponsors: Grand National (1950–1970), Winston Cup (1971–2003), Nextel Cup (2004–2007), Sprint Cup (2008–2016), Monster Energy Cup (2017–2019), NASCAR Cup Series (2020–present).
code: cup <- load_series("cup")

title: NASCAR Series Data — series_data
text: NASCAR's second-tier national series, often considered proving ground drivers aspiring reach Cup Series. debuted 1982 Budweiser Late Model Sportsman Series carried names several title sponsors: Busch Series (1984–2007), Nationwide Series (2008–2014), Xfinity Series (2015–2025), O'Reilly Auto Parts Series (2026–present).   series identifier "nxs", NASCAR's sponsor-neutral abbreviation. avoids tying code single title sponsor.
code: nxs <- load_series("nxs")

title: NASCAR Series Data — series_data
text: NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series features modified pickup trucks racing mix ovals, short tracks, road courses, dirt tracks. launched 1995 SuperTruck Series sponsored names Craftsman Truck (1995–2008), Camping World Truck (2009–2022), Craftsman Truck (2023–present).
code: truck <- load_series("truck")

title: NASCAR Series Data — series_data
text: three series share column structure: Season Integer. Year race took place. Race Integer. Race number within season. Track Character. Name track venue. Name Character. Official race name (includes sponsor). Length Numeric. Track length miles. Surface Character. Track surface type (e.g., "Paved", "Dirt"). Finish Integer. Official finishing position. Start Integer. Starting grid position. Car Character. Car number. Driver Character. Driver's full name. Team Character. Team car owner name. Make Character. Vehicle manufacturer (e.g., "Chevrolet", "Ford", "Toyota"). Pts Integer. Championship points earned. Laps Integer. Total laps completed. Led Integer. Number laps led. Status Character. Race completion status (e.g., "Running", "Crash", "Engine"). S1 Numeric. Stage 1 points (2017–present, NA earlier seasons). S2 Numeric. Stage 2 points (2017–present, NA earlier seasons). S3 Numeric. Stage 3 points. Cup Series , 2024–present (NA NXS, Truck, pre-2024 Cup). Rating Numeric. Driver/loop rating race (NA unavailable). Win Integer. Win indicator (1 = won, 0 = win).

title: NASCAR Series Data — series_data
text: data sourced permission DriverAverages.com updated weekly via automated pipeline. See load_series() access details clear_cache() cache management.

title: nascaR.data 3.0.1
text: Removed disk cache. -disk cache v3.0.0 silently served stale data across R sessions. load_series() now downloads fresh data R2 per session (-memory cache ).

title: nascaR.data 3.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2026-02-14

title: nascaR.data 3.0.0
text: Bundled data removed. cup_series, xfinity_series, truck_series datasets longer shipped package. data now served Cloudflare R2. Use load_series() access data: arrow now required dependency (moved Suggests Imports) since data access goes parquet files R2. "xfinity" series renamed "nxs". second-tier series changed title sponsors four times: Busch (1984-2007), Nationwide (2008-2014), Xfinity (2015-2025), O’Reilly Auto Parts (2026-present). identifier "nxs" NASCAR’s sponsor-neutral abbreviation, never go stale. Replace load_series("xfinity") load_series("nxs"). find_driver(), find_team(), find_manufacturer() removed. get_*_info() functions already include fuzzy matching return actual data. Use get_driver_info("bell") instead find_driver("bell"). data("cup_series") longer works. Replace data() calls load_series(). old lazy-loaded dataset names gone.
code: cup <- load_series("cup") nxs <- load_series("nxs") truck <- load_series("truck")

title: nascaR.data 3.0.0
text: load_series(): Downloads series data R2 caches memory. Subsequent calls within session instant. Use refresh = TRUE force re-download. clear_cache(): New exported function reset -memory cache. R2-canonical pipeline: weekly GitHub Actions scraper now reads existing data R2, appends new races, uploads back R2. local rda files generated committed.

title: nascaR.data 3.0.0
text: Migrated httr httr2 HTTP requests. scraper now uses httr2::request() built-retry logic (req_retry()). Consolidated web scraping httr2, imap_dfr() indexing, explicit column type coercion, placeholder detection, empty table guards. Data validation framework schema, integrity, value checks. Code quality enforced styler lintr (zero warnings). stop() calls package code replaced rlang::abort().

title: nascaR.data 2.2.3
text: CRAN release: 2025-09-11 Adding season updates divisions

title: nascaR.data 2.2.2
text: CRAN release: 2025-06-02 Deprecating weekly branch! Weekly race results added main branch. CRAN-stable version available via CRAN:
code: install.packages("nascaR.data") remotes::install_github("kyleGrealis/nascaR.data") # please do not use "@weekly"

previous_headings: Major Enhancement: Complete Fuzzy Matching System Overhaul
title: nascaR.data 2.2.2
text: Interactive driver/team/manufacturer selection: multiple matches found, users can now select numbered list Intelligent fuzzy matching: Dramatically improved search algorithm handles typos, partial names, word boundaries find_driver("kyle") -> returns Kyle Busch, Kyle Larson, Kyle Petty, etc. find_team("gibbs") -> finds Joe Gibbs Racing find_driver("earnhart") -> correctly finds Earnhardt family drivers Flexible series input: functions now accept character strings data frames get_driver_info("kyle", "cup") check get_driver_info("kyle", "Cup Series") check get_driver_info("kyle", cup_series) check Smart string matching: Handles variations like “cup”, “Cup Series”, “xfinity”, “Xfinity Series” automatically

previous_headings: Major Enhancement: Complete Fuzzy Matching System Overhaul
title: nascaR.data 2.2.2
text: Consolidated codebase: Replaced three separate fuzzy matching files one unified system Priority-based matching: Exact matches > starts > contains > word boundaries > fuzzy similarity Non-interactive mode: Dashboard/script developers can set interactive = FALSE get list returns Removed dependency problematic Levenshtein distance calculations Eliminated interactive prompts broke non-interactive environments

previous_headings: Major Enhancement: Complete Fuzzy Matching System Overhaul
title: nascaR.data 2.2.2
text: Typo tolerance: Common misspellings now find correct matches One-step workflow: Search select function call Clear feedback: Better messaging multiple options available

previous_headings: Major Enhancement: Complete Fuzzy Matching System Overhaul
title: nascaR.data 2.2.2
text: None! existing function calls continue work New interactive parameter defaults TRUE better user experience

previous_headings: Major Enhancement: Complete Fuzzy Matching System Overhaul
title: nascaR.data 2.2.2
text: Fixed fuzzy matching returning irrelevant results Resolved cases obvious matches weren’t found due strict string matching Eliminated interactive readline prompts failed scripts R Markdown

title: nascaR.data 2.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2025-05-15

title: nascaR.data 2.2.1
text: Added missing races. Cup Series season finale omitted number years 2002 2022. Thank Nick Triplett catching mistake! Seg Points removed. Instead, S1 & S2 variables correspond driver’s finishing position segment. Updated missing track information (length, surface type) 32 Cup races varying years, mostly pre-2000s.

title: nascaR.data 2.2.1
text: Updated S1 & S2 documentation.

title: nascaR.data 2.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-01-21

title: nascaR.data 2.1.0
text: dev branch updated recent racing results every Monday 10AM race season (February November). New get_*_info() functions provide summary statistics -race, season, career format. Fuzzy matching included search across database respective series

title: nascaR.data 2.1.0
text: None

title: nascaR.data 2.1.0
text: Updated README vignette reflecting package changes.

title: nascaR.data 2.1.0
text: Error handling placeholder race. “DriverAverages.com” site sometimes one row upcoming race. routinely caused issues weekly scraping functions accidentally “recognizing” completed race. oversight addressed removing (essentially) blank row, decreasing index, continuing scrape new race data. Fuzzy finding used within functions returning driver, team, manufacturer information. room improvement: “Chris Bell” find “Christopher Bell” instead “Chris Miller” now. Improvements include stronger focus driver owner’s last name, take trial error really dial .

title: nascaR.data 2.0.0
text: Web data scraped using R packages & removed existing Python scripts. Reduced number datasets Cup, Xfinity, & Truck series results series . Integrated GitHub Actions auto-updating series results

title: nascaR.data 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-07-09 Initial CRAN submission.
